Problem:
Consider a system described by the differential equation \( \frac{d}{dt} x(t) = Ax(t) \), where A is a constant matrix. We analyze the impact of implementing a Fourier transform \( \mathcal{F}\{x(t)\} \) on x(t) and then applying an inverse Fourier transform to observe the effects on the evolution of x(t) over time.

If at time \( t_1 \), an intervention involving an additional function \( g(x) = Bx(t) \) (where B is a different constant matrix) is applied to \( x(t) \), will the end state \( x(T) \) for T > \( t_1 \) depend uniquely on A?
Explanation: The intervention with the function \( g(x) \) significantly alters the trajectory of the system by introducing a new dynamic component represented by the matrix B. Hence, the final state \( x(T) \) will depend on both matrices A and B, revealing the influence of the intervention.
